rComments: Great professor!

Professor Haddow has studied Ontario and Quebec politics for many years. Readings include his book on the subject matter and academic articles from his colleagues. Topics covered are quite interesting and relevant. Great at adumbrating course concepts. Assessments are a midterm, exam and major essay.

He''s got really organized lectures and gives the slides beforehand so it''s easy to follow along. He does ramble a bit when it gets to the bit on political economy but I''m fairly sure that''s his area of specialty so he also gets more excited about it so I didn''t really mind. Assignments were clear and lectures were always helpful and easy to fill
I enjoyed the lectures and tutorials.  I am glad I took this comparative course, the essays requirements were very clear.

Professor Haddow is very organized, knowledgeable and professional. He is also rather strict and knows if you are listening to him or doing something else. He may seem a bit too straightforward when talking to students, but if you approach him after class or during his office hours, you will see that he is a great guy who cares about his students.

He was great for POl 224 and The Ontario and Quebec Class. He is extremely organized.He is also very aware of your attendance. Do not talk in his class, he will ask you to leave. However, very knowledgeable and engaging if you like CND politics. That being said he is a hard marker but he is fair. Did not get an A but I enjoyed the course!

Makes simple subjects appear complex and confusing. Do not take this class if youre not interested in Canadian politics/history. I was not motivated at ALL. TAs could be helpful. Classes are boring and long (it really drags on). DO.NOT.TAKE.THIS.CLASS. Worst UofT experience thus far

Great material for anyone wishing to properly understand Canada's political institutions. Doing the readings before lecture is KEY. My complaint is that his lecture slides are disorganized and look like notes taken from OTHER lecture slides. They are confusing if you have done the readings and borderline incomprehensible if you haven't.

Professor Haddow is a great professor, he is extremely knowledgeable and a master of his area. He is also nice and friendly. That being said, the class itself is extremely boring because the content is boring and hard. Don't take POL224 if it's not a requirement and/or if you don't love the political system. Grading is very harsh as well.

His lectures are organized, and he follows his slides well (which he posts online before class!) He's enthusiastic, which always helps. At first he was fairly serious, but as the year drew on, he started cracking some fairly unexpected and pretty funny jokes in class. I'd take more courses with him. Definitely do the readings, though.
He is a good prof, and had the best TA who was extremely intelligent

Haddow is great, organized, had a syllabus for the tutorials. Can't say the same for many other profs in the department. I learned so much in his class and the course readers were so much better than borrowing a million books. Reading selections were thematic. Take this class for a good start in PS. You'll grasp the material very well.
I don't like his personality, but he knows his stuff. I would not hesitate to take his class again only because I learnt a lot.

Long boring lectures. This guy is the worst! He gets into tangents and is such an elitist. I learned more in tutorials than in lecture. He should retire already. People skipped and slept in class. I got a good mark though. :)

Boring, boring, boring. Made me lose interest in political science. Extremely vague at points-at times it was very hard to grasp the 'overall picture' or even what were 'supposed' to know. Far too hard for a first year course. I mean, is he doing this on purpose?...Ridiculous amounts of reading. Also tests very demanding (essay-type.) Final mark:73

alright professor - had good powerpoints and made them available - was an okay lecturer but not great - test/exams weren't too hard but they had too many parts in one question and not enough time to answer it fully - the readings weren't super hard, just tedious - the textbook was clear and easy, it reminded me of my gr. 10 civics textbook

Easily the worst class I took in first year. Extremely boring prof, gigantic readings that were extremely hard (course reader at $25 per semester filled with mandatory readings meant for graduate students). Prof could be confusing and tends to ramble for minutes at a time. If you can avoid it DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS.

Haddow was a really good first year prof! i don't understand why people are saying that he was disorganized and that the lectures went over their heads!?! he was really clear with his PP notes and while speaking. The material was a lot to cover and the readings were challenging, but if you keep up with it, it's not impossible to get an A!
Can be confusing if you zone out for a few seconds. Otherwise, he's a very smart guy that is extremely helpful when answering questions.
do not take this class, prof is way confusing, ta's match his hard lectures with hard marking and overall just a terrible course.

As someone who had once intended to major in political science, this course changed my mind. I found that a majority of the ideas went over my head and was far too difficult for a fist year class. The readings were gigantic, and nothing made sense until explained in tutorial. He often went off on long tangents and was incredibly hard to follow.
Worst class that I have ever taken. The Prof may be enthusiastic, but he jumps around alot and is extremely boring.

Many topics in his lectures are totally irrelevant. He jumps around too much. Extremely disorganized in regards to purchasing textbook (4 different books, some including the same readings as others!). At least he knows what he's talking about or else this course would be completely horrible.
Dont take this course. Nice guy....but too confusing. TA's were not helpful. Prof. made the most simplistic ideas...confusing, lectures were too broad...and boring.

This prof is terrible, he jumps around lecture, is completely disorganised with regards to reading material and lecture content. Readings assigned do not coincide with the materials covered in class. Do not take this course, take another Poli Sci option, this prof is really terrible, one of the worst i've had to deal with.

He jumps around in lecture way too much. He is not clear, and is 90% of the time confusing. Bought a textbook that was never used. A LOAD of readings from the course reader ($120 +tax). Attendance is mandatory as no slides are posted on the site. Take POL108 and POL214 for Canadian requirement. In short, Haddow is a terrible prof.

Very enthusiastic, knowledgeable, and likeable. Jumps around a bit in lecture.  Sometimes gets into long tangents, and can be a bit confusing.  Some information overload at times, difficult to know what to focus on in the readings.  Brutal amounts of reading!  Gives essay assignments very early, which is nice.

Professor Haddow has HORRIBLE class control. He is rarely heard, and is too lenient on silly questions. He is also pretty confusing in lecture, and jumps around from subjects. The essay questions he set forth were incredibly ambiguous, this was not a great course.

Fantastic prof! Haddow is very knowledgeable and enthusiastic about teaching (a rarity at U of T). I enjoyed the organized lectures, material and course as a whole. The essay topics were interesting and the TA's were very helpful. This course renewed my faith in professors at U of T.
No Comments

The slides were helpful and he structured his lectures like an essay that argued the different points, that when it came to the exam it was easy to know what kind of questions he was going to ask. He was also very accomodating if you had a problem.
he's really knowledgable and enthused by canadian politics however his enthusiasm doesn't transfer on to the class. lectures often seemed long and boring, made me sleepy.

Professor Haddow runs a very informative class that can become boring with too much information...but still a very helpful and enthusiastic prof...perhaps tell us which part of the reading is important BEFORE THE CLASS
